review.title: Copula Mixture Model for Dependency-seeking Clustering
review.abstract: We introduce a copula mixture model to perform dependency-seeking clustering when co-occurring samples from different data sources are available. The model takes advantage of the great flexibility offered by the copulas framework to extend mixtures of Canonical Correlation Analysis to multivariate data with arbitrary continuous marginal densities. We formulate our model as a non-parametric Bayesian mixture, while providing efficient MCMC inference. Experiments on synthetic and real data demonstrate that the increased flexibility of the copula mixture significantly improves the clustering and the interpretability of the results.

sections.heading: 5.1. Simulated data
sections.text: We simulate two different two-dimensional multi-view datasets with Gaussian intra-view dependency structure. The marginal distributions are Gaussian in the first view, and Beta or Exponential in the second. Each dataset consists of two clusters that can only be identified by taking into account interview dependencies. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: A fundamental aspect of clustering in dependence is that the partition has a semantic interpretation of dependence: the dependencies are captured by the cluster structure. However, this interpretation is only valid if the model is rich enough to adequately match each view, which can be particularly difficult for non-Gaussian data to achieve with existing models. This task becomes even more difficult as the dimensions of the views increase, as the model then allows a wide range of dependencies within the view while allowing for a sufficiently rich dependency structure within the view. The Kopula mixing model offers enough flexibility to cover both aspects: the margins can be specified separately for each dimension and the Gaussian copula allows for a wide range of dependencies within the view. Using a Gaussian copula also facilitates the conclusion and we offer an efficient MCMC mixing model. Experiments with simulated data show that the Kopula mixing model significantly improves cluster results.
